greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Expansion of (theta_3(q)*theta_3(q^7) - 1)/2 in powers of q.
comment: Half the number of integer solutions to x^2 + 7*y^2 = n. - _Jianing Song_, Nov 20 2019
reference: B. C. Berndt, Ramanujan's Notebooks Part III, Springer-Verlag, see p. 302 Entry 17(ii).
formula: a(n) is multiplicative with a(2^e) = |e-1|, a(7^e)= 1, a(p^e) = e+1 if p == 1, 2, 4 (mod 7), a(p^e) = (1+(-1)^e)/2 if p == 3, 5, 6 (mod 7).
program: (PARI) {a(n) = my(x); if( n<1, 0, x = valuation(n, 2); abs(x -1) * sumdiv(n/2^x, d, kronecker(-28, d)))};
(PARI) {a(n) = my(A, p, e); if( n<1, 0, A = factor(n); prod(k=1, matsize(A)[1], [p, e] = A[k, ]; if( p==2, e-1,  p==7, 1, kronecker(-7, p)==-1, (1+(-1)^e)/2, e+1)))};
(PARI) {a(n) = my(A); if( n<1, 0, A = x *O(x^n); polcoeff( (eta(x + A)^-2 * eta(x^2 + A)^5 * eta(x^4 + A)^-2 * eta(x^7 + A)^-2 * eta(x^14 + A)^5 * eta(x^28 + A)^-2 - 1)/2, n))};
xref: Cf. A033719 (number of integer solutions to x^2 + 7*y^2 = n).
results.author: _Michael Somos_, Oct 22 2005
